page.lettertext:
fol.111r
Belgia 1591 stilo Ro
m
16 March To my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591 March:
May it please yo
r
good L. I sent my last before this the 10
th
of
this moneth wherin I made answere to her Ma
t
l
re
of
e first
& to divers of yo
r
L. of severall dates. Howbeit in certain
point
I was driven untill this time to differ mine answere,
tly for that it required some leysure to use such conference
& enquirie, as might satisfie her Ma
ty
,
tly also for that
mine answere depended upon
e resolution of this Councell, w
ch
I could not so speedily
cure as I would, wee have often
bin togeth
r
about th'affaires of Ostend, wh
r
in they have bin moved
as her Ma
ty
required, & as earnestly as might be. But
they again ar as instant to have her Hig
nes
adv
r
tised, that
whatsov
r
shalbee needfull for
e defence of
e place against
the sea or the ennemy shalbee carefully
vided: and for
th'accomlishing therof they have written there unto theyr
officers to c
r
tify
ticularely how ev
r
y thing doth stand.
But they know no consyderac
o
n by w
ch
they should be induced
to strengthen
e town w
th
2 companies more. For they stand
precisely upon yt
t
the Comp
ies
there alredy, w
ch
are 8
at this p
nt
are more then ar needfull. And touching
t
w
ch
hath bin signified
unto
by
e Governo
r
unto them, that
e D. of
Parma is bent, & p
r
pareth to surprise or besiege, or distresse
it some waie, they do not und
r
stand yt to have any good ground.
And theyr officers there in place, w
ch
nev
r
fail to informe of
ev
r
y speciall occurrence, adv
r
tise no such matter. And
albeit it were so, they repute them selves well able to relieve it
in extremity. The gouverno
r
, they think, is therfore
desirous to encrease his companies, that hee might make a
better warre upon the Ennemies countrey, But they on
e other
side are
suaded, that although his exploit
may somwhat
weaken
e ennemy
and thereby benefitt
e c
o
trey
yet any one ov
r
throw, that may bee given
to
e troupes that hee shall send abroade, will more endanger
the town, and endomage theyr estate, then all those litell
warres can turne to theyr good. There are yet besides
some other respect
for w
ch
the Councell doth refuse to assent
fol.111v
Belgia: 1591: March:
to his demand, as they them selves will declare in
theyr letter to her Ma
ty
. I have also rec
o
mended unto
them her Hig
nes
motion for the enlarging of his paie.
Wherin they promise heerafter to do somwhat, as they may
& as they see
e contributions of those quarters will
stretch unto. But as now they saie they are enforced to
husband all unto
e uttermost, to beare theyr necessary charg
The p
nt
entertainem
t
w
ch
is given him is 40
li
a moneth
w
ch
is more then they allow to any oth
r
governo
r
of any
garrison town of theyrs excepting Mons
r
Famma Governo
r
of Hoesden, who in consydera
o
n of his charge, being general
of
e artillery hath also 40
li
monethly & no entertainment
for
t
office. I cannot learne by enquiry, that
there is oth
r
p
r
paration of shipping, by those of Graveling
Dunkerk or newport, then hath bin usuall heertofore, They
have bin buisier of late & mor abroad, then at any time
in
e sommer, becaus the ships of
e states ar wont in
winter to retourn, w
ch
is the time the oth
rs
ob
s
ve to
excercise their piracie. But now
e season is again
t
the States do enter into conference about
e setting forth of
theyr shippes, w
ch
time I do attend to propose in theyr
meeting her Ma
t
pleasure. Becaus I have seen that
letter w
ch
was lately written to yo
r
L. from S
r
Francis Vere
wherin is c
r
tified in
te what is thought upon this sommer
to bee exploited by
e States; & because it
tly belongeth to
S
r
John Norreis report, to whom the States in that matter
have signified somwhat of theyr purpose, I will not trouble
yo
r
L. w
th
a double rehersall. The just acchount that
they have made, howsoever in publick they deliver it
otherwise is to bring at least into
e field 8000 foote a
nd
1800 horse. I have made no mention heer as
yet
the cause, that was sollicited by
e Deputyes of
Flushing
for I have alwaies
understood that the
vittailers
to whom Cap
t
Wingfield, & Randolf were indetted,
have receaved
fol.112r
Belgia: 1591: March:
long ago some
te of satisfaction of
e towne it self of
Flushing, how much I am not certain, but I will endevo
r
by some meanes to know
e c
r
tainty, & c
r
tify yo
r
L.
For as yet I am
suaded, that
e deputies pretence in
behalf of
e widdowes, is a litell peece of cunning to
recover that from her Ma
ty
, w
ch
the towne hath disboursed.
Howbeit if it fall out oth
r
wise, & as they have informed
I will present the matter to
e states to be ended in such
sort as yo
r
L. hath proposed. Yo
r
L. letter of the
25 of Feb
r
was brought but yesterdaie unto mee.
The towne of Nieumegen is much molested every daie
w
th
e sconce that is befor yt, w
ch
wee made
e last sommer.
They have deputed theyr Governo
r
, 2 bu
r
gm
rs
, & 4 burgers
to shew
e D. of Parma, that unles w
th
in a time
w
ch
they have limited unto him they may be freed of
that fort, they will p
nt
ly fall in treaty w
th
e States
of those countreys. This is written to Co. Maurice from a
friend w
th
in
e towne. Although in writinge to
yo
r
L. it may but ill besteem mee, to p
r
fer oth
r
causes
then ar
tinent to my service, yet at M
r
Gilpins very
earnest request, I cannot refuse in his behalf to sollicit
yo
r
L. w
th
all humble entreaty, that his late petition for
succeeding his kinsman John Gilpin may be heard w
th
such
favor, as either yo
r
L. may vouchsafe of yo
r
self or by yo
r
honorable meanes may be easily procured. Being greatly
charged w
th
a family of children, & having nothing in assurance
for
e staye of his living hee is very carefull in minde to
vide
him self of some estate. How well hee hath de
s
ved for his
painefull endevours in her Ma
t
service
buisines, and also for
herafter, how much it may behove to have his service heer
continued, as no man can consider better then yo
r
L. so I
put him in good comfort that no man wilbe redyer to reward or
recommend him, when occasyon is p
nt
ed. It is
e opinion
heer of many, &
e like is advertised by divers out of Brabant
fol.112v
Belgia: 1591: March:
that
e D. of Parma is staied from eith
r
going himself or
sending into Fraunce. For
e new supply of succors
t
shall
bee sent from
e Pope, & shall come out of Spaine, is thought
enough to
s
ve
e turne for any purpose in France
& in
t
respect it is reported
t
these great preparations
of
e Duke in
es countreys are wholy for
e warr
t
hee
is bent to make heer, &
t
his principall dessigne
is to besiege Breda. notw
th
standing
t
answere
that I have given to
e Councel, as yo
r
L. willed in yo
r
letter of
e 13 of Feb
r
they are sutors once againe
that I should move her Ma
ty
in theyr behalf for
e
augmenta
o
n of
e 4 horseband
t
are heer in her
Ma
t
paie to
e numb
r
of 120. They are thorouly
suaded
t
if her Hig
nes
would refer yt to theyr
agreem
t
w
th
e Captaines, they should take such order
as they should all be contented, as these contrey captaines
have bin alredy to accept
e allowance of 20
sh
for
ev
r
y horse, & to have
eir armor of
e Countrey. w
ch
shalbee
deducted upon their paie in 3 moneths, wh
r
by they infer
that
e whole for so litell a space as they demand yt
w
ch
is but 6 or 7 moneths, will amount but to
e somme
of 700
li
ster
l
or th
r
about. Being very
solemly & earnestly entreated to motion this again, as
a matter of
t
nature,
t
may greatly advance
e
service toward
, & grow in
e whole to a very small
charge, I leave yt to yo
r
L. to be reported to her
Hig
n es
.
& take my humble leave. From
e Hage
March 16 1590.
